measured_by: ratings on four approach-emotion items (excited, optimistic, interested, confident) using a 1–5 Likert scale
justification: “Participants then rated their emotional reaction … on a scale from 1 (Very little or not at all) to 5 (Extremely) on four approach emotions (excited, optimistic, interested, confident).”

measured_by: ratings on three avoidance-emotion items (bored, pessimistic, disconnected) using a 1–5 Likert scale
justification: The same sentence notes that participants also rated “…three avoidance emotions (bored, pessimistic, disconnected)” on the 1–5 scale as a manipulation check.

measured_by: self-reported confidence in the amount invested on a 1–7 Likert scale
justification: Participants later evaluated each argument on “the positive effect on their confidence in the amount they invested” using a 1 (Strongly disagree) to 7 (Strongly agree) scale, and these confidence ratings were analysed in the ANOVAs.

measured_by: self-reported ratings of satisfaction, confidence, and quality for each argument on a 1–7 Likert scale
justification: Participants “…rated two arguments … on three dimensions on a scale from 1 (Strongly disagree) to 7 (Strongly agree): the positive effect … on satisfaction…, the positive effect on their confidence…, and the quality of the argument,” which were treated as relevance judgments.
